text: I took 2 bags of old clothes to the nearest recycling bin about a mile away. When I got there, the bin wasn't there. I had walked 20 minutes in the sweltering sun carrying these heavy bags for nothing. The nearest suitable bin was now 2 miles away. Then it hit me. This must be what it's like being poor. Two giant bags weighing you down. Making your life harder. Everything is slower and tougher. This opened my eyes completely. I dropped the bags then and there right in the street. Why choose to be poor? Simply drop the bags.

I decide whether it's worth hiring a candidate based on just one question: `Can you do a wheelie?` Years ago when I was in school I asked my crush if she wanted to go to the dance. She said no. `Sorry I'm waiting for Todd to ask me. He can do 100 wheelies. I can't go to the dance with someone who can't do wheelies.` Ever since then, I have decided who can do wheelies are vapid, showy and have a stupid face. If a candidate says they can do a wheelie, I refuse to hire them. Until yesterday, when a candidate walked in and proudly said he could do wheelies. That candidate was Todd. And I hired him, because it was time to be the bigger man. I'm going to make Todd's life a living hell.

I have been neglecting my son. Sometimes, it happens. The late hours. The yacht parties. The trips overseas. More yacht parties. The networking events. Many many yacht parties. I hadn’t seen my son for 14 months. I had to do something about it. That’s when I turned to Lovable . Lovable is a platform that allows anyone of any skill level to build apps and websites using AI - I figured even a 6 year-old could use it. I told him to build a replacement AI father. It worked. I didn’t hear from him for another 3 months. That’s when I started to miss him. I thought, “this is ridiculous.” So I turned to Lovable and built an AI replacement son. Perfect. We're closer than ever before. Thank you Lovable , for giving us the father-son relationship we never had.

The radiologist called me yesterday. It sounded serious. They said they spotted an anomaly on my x-rays. I was prepared for the worst. They found a strange shape and the word `Quantamonster.` That's the company logo of my new startup. Years ago I asked a surgeon to engrave it onto my patella. Now, every time I go for an X-Ray, the radiologist sees it, gets intrigued. If they search it, they'll find that we've just opened a new seed round. They sign up. Some say for raising investor money, you need to think outside the box. I say you need to think inside the body. Venture capitalism is in my bones.

An incident happened at work yesterday. It involved me and an employee and potential toxic behaviour. HR called me in to sign a declaration. The declaration read: `I, Ken Cheng, will always be a messy bitch.` Problem solved. The Messy Bitch Clause protects me from all legal ramifications from my chaotic actions. Now, if anything comes up that looks like bullying, harassment, discrimination, people will say: `No, it's not toxic. He's just a Messy B.` `His intentions cannot be harmful. Messy B's can't intentionally cause harm.` `He always throw staplers. That's classic Messy B behaviour.` Phew. I am safe to be my true self, and I will always endeavour to stay true to myself. By being the messiest bitch boss of all time. Now I can't be sued for it. I have the best lawyers.

I listed a packet of ramen on FB Marketplace. It was expired by 3 years 5 months. It sold instantly. Guess it's listing price. £700. How? Because no one else is selling expired ramen on there. That's called a gap in the market. Anything can be turned into a product - you just have to start selling it. A good businessman listens to demand. A great businessman creates it. It's the same with my LinkedIn. Nobody else is offering wisdom like me, and that's why it works. My LinkedIn is expired ramen.

I'm sorry. I have reached the 30,000 maximum limit of LinkedIn connections. This is egregious. Who is LinkedIn to say that I cannot have 30,001 deep spiritual bonds. This is an absolute disgrace. It reminds me of when I was sleeping with 30 women and they all found out. They responded fascistically, saying I couldn't do that. Who is anyone to put a limit on who I connect my mind and flesh with? Both LinkedIn and my many ex-girlfriends keep trying to police my relationships. I'm sorry, but this means only one thing. The cull has begun. Justify your place in the hashtag # Ken30000 .

I have been silenced. This time it was not by traditional media. It was not by the woke left. Not by the theatre usher for saying `bloody hell` during Hamlet. I have been silenced on the subreddit r/LinkedInLunatics. A year ago my posts were featured on the front page every day. I didn't care that I was labelled a `lunatic`, many greats were. As long as people saw my wisdom, civilisation was making progress. At some point, I became too powerful. There were always three or four of my posts at the top. This led to the invention of `Satire Saturdays`, which resulted in the deletion of my posts not on a Saturday. Here's the problem: my posts are not satire. Groundbreaking philosophy can sometimes feel like satire because it is so avant-garde and interesting. What's next? I have to sit at the back of the bus because those are the `Satire Seats`? My children have to go to the specific `Satire School`? This is segregation at its finest. UPDATE: The subreddit mods have requested that people do not harass them on the subreddit and I will echo that statement. While I wanted people to peacefully protest this ruling, it can very quickly veer into abuse and I do not want that. Keep things respectful.

Happy Valentine's Day to my latest beau. Took pictures of her at work to commemorate. Yes, work. Yes, she is one of my employees. Yes, I hired her because I wanted to date her. No, there is nothing wrong with that. Believe it or not, there is no such thing as a power imbalance. Because even though I have power in that I can fire her, she has power because she can break up with me, so we are equal. It's actually very sexist to assume she doesn't have any power just because I decide her salary and make her do what I want at any time. Power imbalance implies weakness. She is not weak. In fact she is stronger than I'll ever be. Because I could never date my boss. That takes real strength.

Followers on LinkedIn, I need to say a few words. I would like to make a sincere apology for my previous post, advertising an event I am hosting and claiming that I will `literally die` if it doesn't sell out. The truth is: that was a lie. This was a heat of the moment lapse of judgement and I am sorry to those hurt by this. Lying to people in order to make a quick profit is something that goes against my values and something a CEO would never do. I did what I did for one simple reason alone. My family has been kidnapped by terrorists and they told me I had to make that post. It felt horrible though. It was not me. In the coming months, I am going to seek therapy and practice a lot of self reflection. After that, I will be absolved of all sins that `pre-therapy Ken` did because it was a completely different person. Until then, I'll be taking time away from LinkedIn to spend time trying to find my family.

The best asset a successful man can have? A woman. But not just any woman. The one who has immense intelligence. Boundless wisdom. And endless great ideas. Ideas you can steal. Ideas you can pass off as your own at work. Ideas that make people ask `how did you think of that?` and you shrug and say `I guess I'm just an outside the box thinker.` She's happy taking no credit. She's completely fine living in your shadow. Giving calm, quiet support. No drama. You can mine her ideas forever, like a golden goose. A man who has this has the one thing we all dream of: Free management consultancy at home. Give a man that and... He will give you an OK life.

My 9 year old son is getting bullied at school. Most parents would step in and get involved themselves. Not me. I referred him to an LLM. He used AI to come up with witty comebacks to deploy against his bullies, that were a mix of Voltaire quotes and rhyming disses. They worked. The whole school were so impressed by his oratory skills he became popular overnight. This became an issue. He started refusing to do his homework. When I asked him to do chores he would hit me with another French Philosopher. Daniel started to think of himself a God. He had to be stopped. Did I turn to ChatGPT? No, I could see the dangers of AI. I paid a child £5 to pants him. He was humiliated in front of the entire school and balance was restored. AI may have become very powerful but it will never replace the traditional methods.

I can understand this man's anger. For those who haven't seen Montoya yet, it's a must watch. I relate. Not because I would get mad watching my wife with another man. That didn't bother me at all. At first, I couldn't get what the problem was. But then, I had a similar experience. I saw my ex-employee Wes having lunch with his new boss. They were discussing deadlines, KPIs and also sharing inside jokes. Seeing Wes laugh made me feel like Montoya watching his woman get railed. I was overcome with rage. I felt like ripping up my own £6,000 suit, running across the restaurant screaming and tackling the boss. So I did. I'm not proud of it. But I don't regret it either. I'm passionate about my employees. Is acting on that and assaulting a stranger a crime?

⚠️ Here are things I've had to do as a boss for my employees that don't appear in any job description 🔷 Pick up an employee's child from school because they were working late 🔷 Let an employee stay in my guest house because they were going though a divorce 🔷 Host an impromptu birthday party with 4 hours notice 🔷 Receive a panicked phone call from same employee at 2am that night 🔷 Help formulate a plan as they think they hit a deer 🔷 Get up and drive 15 miles to where they are 🔷 Arrive to find them sobbing 🔷 Find out it wasn't a deer, it was a human 🔷 Calm them down by saying it probably was a hitchhiker with no family 🔷 Haul the body into my trunk 🔷 Drive out to a river to dump it in 🔷 It won't sink 🔷 Get some petrol and a match to burn it 🔷 Next morning get into work, turn on the news and see a missing person report for the CTO of our biggest rival 🔷 It's the guy 🔷 Our stock price jumps up 🔷 Win-win 🔷 Agree to never tell a soul Being a boss isn't just emails and deadlines. It's real everyday human moments that we all experience. It's truly living.

I saw Stonehenge. Overrated. I thought it would be a spiritual experience considering its history, but nothing. Just some rocks. There wasn't even Wi-Fi. Talk about lack of modernisation. It's nothing compared to my favourite spot in the world: Westfield Shopping Centre. That is a sight to behold. An architectural marvel. Thousands of people and businesses. Millions of pounds changing hands per minute. At Stonehenge, the sparse gift shop and car park were far away, and you had to walk over lots of grassland. It's disheartening to see so much money being left on the table. It truly felt like being in the Dark Ages. There wasn't even an ethernet port.

A lot of people want to be rich to own a fast car. Or to live in a massive mansion. Or to sleep with thousands of beautiful women. Not me. My quest for wealth is for one simple reason alone. I want to be able to walk around holding two giant bags of money with dollar signs on them, while wearing a top hat and bowtie. Private jets. Swimming pools. Hareems of women. None of these matter to me. All that matters to me is I can walk around town in my tuxedo holding a cane with a dollar sign on top. A lot of people want to own empires, influence governments, have immense power. I don't care about that. I just want to be able to go up to people and tell them they came second place in a beauty contest, or send them directly to jail. For me, this is the height of success. I'm not like other billionaires.

Since becoming a millionaire I struggle to connect with my poor friends. Why? I haven't changed. Why do they treat me differently? Because I have a fast car? Because my watch costs more than their yearly rent? Or is it because I like to dangle a £50 note above them and make them bark like a dog? I'm still the same human being. I still breathe the same air. I just like to tell them to go `woof woof` and beg in a little doggy voice. I don't understand. I think it's jealousy. Or a lack of empathy. If they were in my shoes they'd also make their friends roll over and behave like an animal for money. It's unfair. I've been ostracised just for my affectionate nature. A man's best friend is his dog. A rich man's best friend is his friend Jake who he dresses in a big dog onesie and calls Rex. I miss my best friend Rex.

The funniest man on the internet? Ken Cheng If you haven't seen one of his ridiculous posts on Linkedin.... Where have you been? On this week of the podcast we talk about all things humour and corporate nonsense Search `We Have A Meeting` where you get your podcasts

I was in the waiting room outside my therapist's office and I always end up sitting next to a guy who looks incredibly depressed. I know you're not supposed to talk to each other but when I see a problem, I need to fix it. `What's wrong?` I said. `I'm at rock bottom. I keep thinking what's the point.` He replied. Hmm. `Are you on LinkedIn? Check out this account.` I pass over my phone and it's my own account. I show him several of my own inspirational posts and his face starts to light up. First time I've seen him smile. The next week I go, he's not there. Same the week after. Two months go by and I finally see him again. He goes straight up to me and grabs me. `Hey man, I wanted to thank you. Since you showed me your posts, I've been happier and more motivated than I've ever been. I went home and cancelled therapy because with your LinkedIn, I don't need it anymore.` He gave me a big hug and said, `you seem so well-adjusted. Why are you in therapy?` `I'm not.` I haven't been for years. But I do go to my old therapist's waiting room now and then to help those who need it. When I see a problem, I fix it.

Wokeness has ruined one of the oldest, most reliable business practices. It is now illegal to dress up as a ghost and haunt an abandoned amusement park to drive the price down so you can buy it. I've been doing this for decades on weekends. The Headless Horseman. Viscount Francis the Cursed Phantom. The Mutated Chicken. All concoctions of mine from the past used to deter buyers. I once hid in the walls of a top floor penthouse making goat noises for 2 months. That became my bachelor pad. But now, you're at risk of being cancelled by Gen Z mystery detectives if you do such a thing. These days you can get arrested for simply trespassing on private land and harassing potential business owners, which I was. I would have gotten away with it too had it not been for Woke Britain (and the police).

I often talk to homeless people and ask them `why don't you have a job` They all answer the same way `I don't need one, I earn so much passive income from my Nvidia stock` `I'm actually a board member of Apple and my net worth is in the millions` `I just do this to feel alive again, it feeds into my humiliation kink` This is the actual truth. No one is actually homeless, they are all multimillionaires who enjoy cosplaying And it just goes to show, no matter how much money you earn you still get bored That's why our economy is broken Society has forgotten about the top 1% and now they're forced onto the streets It's all well and good rewarding our heroic shareholders with money but society needs to do more to keep them entertained We need more hobbies for rich people

8 years ago we were in a MISERABLE marriage. Our house wasn't a HOME, It was a WARZONE. Here's how we fixed it: 1) I accidentally shrunk our two children with the shrinking machine I invented Suddenly, everything was so quiet again. It was PARADISE. Every day = no CHORES Every evening = date night, no KIDS Every night = raucous sex, on every SURFACE The responsibility of supporting and nurturing our young children was really killing my vibe. It took us 72 hours to realise they were missing. Eventually we found them and we unshrunk them. Phew. But really, the real thing that got unshrunk that week was our brains. We learned so much from their absence. 2) We shipped our children off to boarding school

When people talk about loneliness, homelessness and mental illness, all I see are dollar signs. Why? Because I have a rare condition where I can't tell the difference between the letter 's' and '$'. My brain reads them the same loneliness / loneline$$ assassin / a$$a$$in po$$e$$ionle$$ne$$e$ / po$$e$$ionle$$ne$$e$ They look the exact $ame to me. I'm being bombarded every day with the notion of profit. I think this is why I've had so much $ucce$$. When you always see money in front of you, it's hard not to reach out and grab it. It's a ble$$ing not a cur$€.

I went on a date last night with an elite-level female. She had 10/10 attractiveness, 9/10 intelligence, and a great sense of humour (laughed at all my jokes). What was the problem? She didn't have an MBA. Frankly, her lack of business expertise gave me the ick. We went to a Italian restaurant where I couldn't help notice the poor business practices in play. Missed opportunities, shoddy use of the space, very little done to minimise costs. Contrast to: when I'm out with my best friends - 5 MBAs between them, and there are only 3 of them - they would have each come up with 5 ways this restaurant could improve on the spot. She said nothing. Now, I chose this restaurant as a test to see how she'd react. She failed. I don't care how many astrophysics PhDs you have (in her case, one), true intelligence comes from one thing: having an MBA.

My daughter walked away from a car crash last week Luckily she was unscathed It was on a busy intersection in the middle of town Everyone was watching Which is why I plastered her car with adverts for my company Completely covered in website details and qr codes Bystanders were worried for her life but also intrigued about cheaper backend web development You know they say `it was like a car crash I couldn't look away` Advertisers would kill for that level of engagement retention My daughter gets in a lot of car crashes It wasn't luck She's a professional stunt driver 💪

What if you could undergo a procedure where your non-work memories are separated from your work memories? Perfect. I'd do it in a heartbeat. I absolutely hate not being at work. Nothing worse than leaving the office to go back to the gruelling unchallenging home I share with my family. I wish I could be transported back to the office and it's 8am the next day. That's where my real family are. What is there to do at home? Eat? Watch TV? Have sex? I often do all three at work anyway. The only thing that would stop me is knowing I'd be resigning my outside self to a life of never answering another email, filling in another spreadsheet or making a PowerPoint deck ever again. Pure torture. I call this procedure `Partition.` I hope somebody invents it soon.

My 7 year old son noticed at his school that one of the climbing frames kept giving the children splinters. He told the school about it. They refused to do anything. He kept telling them to fix it every day. They still refused. He started writing letters and emails every hour he was at home. They ignored them. He started a petition, and went round to every student to get them to sign it, then went to their parents' houses and got their parents to sign it. Still nothing. He had lost all hope. He almost gave up. Then, he had an idea: he set up his own stall by the climbing frame. He charged to remove splinters, treat splinter wounds and sold everyone cheap splinter insurance. The school never did anything, but at least my son made a killing. Activism doesn't work. Profiteering does.

Word of my business leadership skills have circulated and I've been invited to a panel talk. I was told The `C` Word was CEO but the talk is actually about being Chinese in Britain. Luckily I am also an expert on that according to Malcolm Gladwell's 10,000 hour rule. This Friday. British Library.

I stopped washing my hands. Why? Because it doesn't make me any money. Has it negatively affected any major business deals? Have my profits gone down? Has even a single person commented? The answers to those are `no`, `no` and `all the time`, respectively. But it's only the first two that matter. Whenever you take any action, the only thing I ask is, `does this add to my bottom line?` If the answer is no, I stop doing it. Simple. I haven't washed my hands since 2017, saving a valuable 3 seconds that I was wasting every bathroom trip. While you're out there worrying about so-called `clean hands`, I'm choosing profit. I'm min-maxing weeing.

I know someone who is currently in his 12th round of interviews for a consultant position. Drew has been called back for interview after interview, each one asking him to generate new ideas to improve the company's business. He should pull out, but he desperately wants this job. How do I know him? I'm the one interviewing him. Drew is actually 1 of 15, all being considered for the same role. Except, the role will never be filled. It doesn't need to. The several applicants are between them doing the job for free. All they have is the vague promise of something real. I've called it the `work situationship`. And it's revolutionised employment. A shame that they have so little self respect and don't quit. I have no choice but to exploit them.

Time for a history lesson. I actually invented the term `competitive salary`. Before, job offers would tell you the actual salary. Yuck. No, it's much better the applicant is kept in the dark for as long as possible. Would you tell someone everything you can offer on the first date? No, there is something called `mystique`. The mystique of not knowing the pay makes a job much sexier. A bunch of recruiters and CEOs got in a room and had a massive brainstorming session. It lasted 72 hours. We threw a bunch of ideas around. `Good salary` was too limp and vague. `High salary` was promising too much. `Sexy salary` was great alliteration, but did we really want people thinking they could have sex with their salary? That's when I had it...`competitive salary.` We could picture it now. Applicants reading it and thinking `wow, this salary is COMPETITIVE. It's the Michael Phelps of salaries. My salary could beat up your salary.` It was perfect. It said so much while not committing to anything at all. When those golden words left my mouth, everyone in that room knew I had changed recruiting forever. I received a 3 minute standing ovation and I did six laps of high fives, then crowdsurfed out of there.

Rejection is painful. For the person doing the rejection as well as the person being rejected. It hurts me so much to tell someone I'm crushing their dreams. I feel like George in Of Mice and Men, taking Lennie out and shooting him in the back of the head. I feel like I'm taking a life. That's why as an employer I never send out a rejection email. No matter how many interviews they have, they will never see a formal rejection out of me. It's too painful. People call this `ghosting`. I call it `giving hope`. There is no better feeling than waiting to hear back from a job interview. That hopeful feeling of endless potential. I let people live with that hope forever. I'm never pulling that trigger, Lennie.

£10,000 or my book? I asked a random woman on the street which she would rather take. I fully expected her to say the money instead of a book that'll be available in regular stores for £15. She did say the £10,000. A huge mistake. Why? Inside my book I had hidden £50,000 in cash. By being greedy, this woman made a net loss of £40,000. The lesson? When someone offers you money or their book, always take the book in case it has £50,000 hidden inside it.

This may come as a shock, but even I suffer from Imposter Syndrome at work. Every day I think I don't deserve to be here, and I've taken someone else's place. I feel like a total imposter. Because I am. One day, I met a man on a secluded beach. He asked me to look after his clothes and bag while he went for a swim. The tides were particularly violent that day. I watched him get swept up by the ocean; I knew he wasn't coming back. I check his bag. In it was his passport, his birth certificate, £100k in cash and a 50-page document titled `How To Impersonate Me If I Die At Sea`. His name was Ken Cheng. I stole the real Ken Cheng's identity. I stole his assets. I stole his life. I am an imposter. And boy it feels good.

Today, I did the unthinkable. I deleted one of my LinkedIn posts. To my loyal followers, from the bottom of my heart, I am sorry. It just wasn't good enough. `Why does that matter? They're just posts,` an idiot might say. People are relying on my posts for business advice. When they aren't good, people die. I'm like a brain surgeon, but of the mind. Except a brain surgeon is only responsible for one life at a time. I'm responsible for 108,000. My Grandfather was one of the first soldiers on the beaches of Normandy. He said to me, `I don't know how you have the bravery to post on LinkedIn.` He's right. Every time I post I feel like I'm at the front of the boat, machine gun in hand, ready to take the beach. It takes a lot of bravery. And I failed last time. I let down my country. But I won't give up. Next time, I will take the beach.

I don’t care if you choose to work from home or not. I don't care if you come in 3 hours late and smell of tequila. I don't care if you play Minesweeper while we're on a Teams call. I don't care if you watch cartoon animal porn in the office during work hours. Life happens! I hired you for a job and I only care about one thing: I'm allowed to completely exploit you and disregard your employment rights at any time. If you are willing to be treated like a soulless profit delivering machine, you can do whatever you want. You don’t need to justify a day off, as long as you make up for it by working 24 hours without overtime pay. You don’t need to explain how traffic was bad, as long as you drive me to the airport later. You don't need to apologise for having a personal life, as long as you invite me along and introduce me to your hot single friends. Yes, I care about results but I also care about exerting my power and dominance to make myself feel big. That's why I became a CEO. My advice for anyone hiring: 1. Select people who are too naïve or meek to say anything while you treat them like a worm 2. Make sure they own headphones (for the animal porn) 3. They have hot friends 4. Get out of their way. Agree?

Hiring isn't always morally straightforward. I found a perfect candidate but there was one catch. He had a long history of financial crime. Truly an ethical quandary. Do I protect my reputation and move on? Would that be doing this man a disservice though? Everyone deserves a fifth chance. I had a solution. In the interview, I looked him in the eye and asked him to say “I will not do crime ever again.” He did. I then provided a picture of his mother and asked him to hold it and swear on her life. He did. Phew. I believed him. But I still needed to make sure. After he left, I tailgated him for several hours. I watched him go to the shops, pick up his children, then I parked outside his home for a bit and watched him watch Netflix until he got tired and got into bed with his wife. He didn't commit a single crime once. That was good enough for me.

One of my employees, Sean, was on a first date and it wasn't going so well. He went to the bathroom and texted me for advice. Most bosses would say this is a breach of boundaries, but I stopped reading to my son to call Sean immediately. He wanted to give up and go home. `No Sean,` I said. `There is no deal that's impossible to close. Just be honest with her.` He got back to the table and told her he was nervous so he called his boss (me). `Who's your boss?` `His name is Ken Cheng.` `You work for Ken Cheng?!` Her body language changed immediately. They talked for hours about their favourite posts of mine and, afterwards, she invited him back to hers. Become such a great boss that even the mere mention of working for you gets your employees laid.

The gym isn't just a place for physical self-improvement, but mental too. I go to the same gym as Diary of a CEO's Steven Bartlett. I've gained so much from just being in the same changing room. I've never actually spoken to him, but there are other ways to get to know someone. Here's what I've learned about business by smelling his used towel. 1. Even his sweat smells successful. I've changed my diet 50 times to try and find this perfect rich man odour. 2. He never uses a towel twice. I had to dig the towel out of a bin. He is so rich every good is a perishable good. 3. He spells out dollar signs with the way he dries himself, or the symbol of a currency that's doing well in ForEx currently. Manifest even when wet. Soon, I'll know him well enough to make the first move (steal his phone while he's in the shower to take 33 selfies of me holding my business card)

There is no such thing as a toxic boss. Bosses are simply trying to help you achieve your maximum potential. That sometimes hurts. Think of it like hot soup. The soup is trying to give you heat and warmth, but sometimes the soup will be too hot and it burns your mouth. That's not the soup's fault. You wouldn't call the soup toxic. The soup loves you, and was just trying to help keep you warm. It was you that burned yourself by not waiting for it to cool down. Similarly, your boss loves you and is simply trying to help you become more efficient with their management style. Sometimes that management style is too hot and will make you cry in the toilet. But other times, it will help you grow as a person. You need to be more patient with your boss, just like with your soup. It's you that's hurting yourself. You're the one who's toxic. The bottom line: thinking about your boss like he's hot soup will help you understand and forgive all the times he hurt you.

I once put a candidate through 5 rounds of interviews over 2 months with no intention of hiring him. Why didn't I just reject him straight away? For fun. I kept him on the hook because I enjoyed messing with him. I got to know Andy very well. I learned all about his family, his backstory, and just how much getting this job would mean to him. I loved wasting his time and putting him through hell. Interviewers want nothing more than to have complete power over someone's future. I felt like I had this man's dreams in my hands, and crushing them made me feel alive. Nobody enjoys the hiring process. One person might as well get some fun out of it. Remember this every time you go for an interview: you are nothing but an antelope to the interviewer’s lion.

`Strategies to avoid burnout.` `How to prevent burnout.` `Burnout is a killer.` No. Burnout is actually good. There are many great things that have been achieved because of intense burnout. Inventing the iPhone. Making Apocalypse Now. Winning World War II. The truth is, if you push past max burnout, the human brain resets, like getting a score so high on an arcade machine it wraps around to zero. This is called `burn-in`. Burn-in is a state of true enlightenment that can only be reached by not eating, sleeping or even drinking properly, and riding off pure adrenaline - that's what it's for. Scientifically, we have evolved to work past legal working hours. You sometimes hear people say `I worked so hard I have nothing left.` Good. It means you're maximising your potential. That's burn-in. This is why I push my workers to the edge. The stress they feel is only their brains being too afraid to succeed. They say that diamonds are made under pressure. Well, do you want to make diamonds, or do you want to `practise self-care`? I'm making diamonds every time. I'm burning in.

I was on a first date and during dinner, my date got a call on her phone. `Just my boss,` she says quickly and puts her phone away. MASSIVE ick. If she is not willing to prioritise her career over a relative stranger, then how will she climb the ladder? What else is she going to prioritise over her work? Parties? Holidays? Our future children? I can't imagine a future with someone who lacks so much drive and sacrifice. I'm not getting laid at all and the company is going into liquidation. But the important part is no one knows either of those. The truth is what you make it.

Ken Cheng is a professional comedian, but you'd only know that if you spent 5 seconds googling him That's way too much to ask of r/linkedinlunatics Join Ken and I for a conversation about everybody's favorite subreddit

99.99999999% of sperm don't make it. It's only the elite sperm that rises to the top and succeed. This statistic is the same in business. Most entrepreneurs fail, either falling behind the fastest swimmers like myself or launch their company into a toilet bowl only to be flushed away. I was one of the elite few that made it. I still remember being a little sperm, racing past my competitors, because I had a single goal in mind: get to the egg. That determination. That tenacity. That pace. With that same determination, you'll be able to achieve anything you want, whether it's impregnating an egg or setting up a box park retail store. I was The Sperm That Lived. Be that sperm.

The haters have finally come for me (see pic below). In the same way the Romans were not ready for Jesus, the world truly is not ready for my teachings. It's true what they say. Sufficiently advanced Linkedin wisdom is indistinguishable from magic. I have turned water (bad LinkedIn posts) into wine (life changing wisdom that will get you laid). And now I know exactly what it's like to be crucified. If they ban my posts from r/linkedinlunatics, it'll be no different from nailing my wrists to a giant LinkedIn Logo. First they came for the LinkedIn CEOs, and you did not speak up because you're not as rich as me. Well it is time now to speak up.

It's time to speak up against rigged raffles at charity events. I bought 25 tickets to a raffle yesterday, hoping to score big. The raffle winners were drawn by a 9 year old child which I didn't question. As the prizes started being read out, more and more started going to different volunteers of the event. Then, I realised the child was the daughter of one of the volunteers. I'd heard about this: children who were well trained in the art of sleight of hand from birth. The last straw was when the child was the winner of my most wanted prize. I called the police. I told them there were several counts of child labour, children involved in gambling and the illicit rigging of the charity raffle. When the police showed up, it caused such a commotion that I used the opportunity to wrestle the prize off the child (she had magic fingers but she was weak). I ran home, clutching my new prized Lego Minecraft set. I will always seek to call out injustice, no matter how small.

As I currently wade through my third divorce I think about what lessons I can learn from it in business, and how I can bring DIVORCED energy to the workplace. D - Determination (I now have way more time to work now that I am alone) I - Integrity (I will act with complete integrity unlike when I cheated on my ex-wife) V – Vision (I will use my vision to ogle my attractive employees more) O – Opportunity (I will have the opportunity to play PS5 and finish Spider-Man) R – Resilience (I will cry less often) C – Creativity (I will find creative ways to act out my insecurities on my employees and make their lives hell to fuel my ego instead of seeking therapy) E – Efficiency (I am now sleeping in my office, which saves time) D – Divorced (I am divorced) How are you being DIVORCED in the business sector today?

If I had to choose between: a) £1 million in cash or b) getting my gooch tickled by Albert Einstein I would choose b). No question. I've received £1 million many times, but the experience of the smartest man ever to live reaching down and lightly touching your taint would be unique and irreplaceable. Go hog wild, Einie.

Yes I would pay my workers less than minimum wage. Yes I would dodge my taxes if it was legal. Yes I would make my employees work 80 hours a week. Yes I would build a Terminator-like robot to hunt down my competitors. Yes I would also use it on anyone who skives off work to go to the football. Yes I would employ child labour. I'm not perfect. That's why these laws exist. I'm a human with human needs and human flaws. And it's okay to admit that. No one else is brave enough to.

I was called into school because my 11 year old son got into trouble with his English teacher. All the kids bring in books to read at the start of the lesson. He brought in The Prince by Machiavelli. My teacher took it away from him and said it wasn't suitable for children. `Why?` My son asked. `Because it teaches people to gain power at any cost, which is not a good lesson.` `Interesting.` My son leaned back. `How did you become a teacher?` `I went to university and got an education degree.` `Okay. So let me get this straight, you spent several years of your life and tens of thousands of pounds, just so you can be the autocratic ruler of a small state where you can control the media and dictate what views are suitable and unsuitable? Doesn't that seem a bit... Machiavellian?` Her jaw dropped. The next day, every kid in the class brought in their own copy of The Prince by Machiavelli.

I started playing chess against my new employee, Beth. For ages, I was beating her, but she studied up and improved, and I was losing consistently. I didn't mind losing at all, but it made me really angry that the other employees started making jokes about how I was being beaten. They would say `hey why are you our boss instead of Beth? She's obviously smarter than you`. Again, it wasn't the losing that bothered me, but the way I was being disrespected. Things came to a head when I flipped the chessboard after a tenth loss in a row (the loss did not upset me at all.) My head of sales made this moment into a meme with the caption `1200 ELO scrub`. This annoyed me to no end (unlike the loss itself, which I was 100% cool with.) Beth's performance review was coming up. I told her that her spending too much time getting good at chess was making her job performance worse, as well as hurting office morale, and could mean her being let go. After that, I started beating her at chess again every time. It felt good to win again, though I really didn't mind losing.

The other day I was in a cafe and I overheard three women nursing their newborn babies having a conversation. One of them said, `I've been playing classical music for my son because I want him to be in an orchestra.` Another chimed in, `I've been showing mine football compliation videos because I want her to be a famous sports star.` The third mother, smirked a bit, and said `I've been reading mine Linkedin posts by an entrepreneur called Ken Cheng. I'm hoping he'll be a ruthless and successful CEO like he is.` The others' eyes suddenly opened wide. `Can you share some of his wisdom? A CEO is way more impressive than being a musician or footballer.` `Of course,` the third mother said. Then, her baby coughed and pulled at his mother's top. `What's the matter, David?` David pointed at one of the other's babies cute red bow they were wearing. `Oh I see. I'll share one of his lessons if you give me Kirsty's red bow.` Kirsty's Mum immediately relented and David now had the bow. `That's one of Ken's first lessons: never give anything away for free.` I always knew my advice was universal, but I never thought babies would be picking up on it. Amazing.

What would you tell your younger self if you could? For me, it would be exactly what I was told 20 years ago. When I was younger I was visited by a man in his 40s who claimed to be me from the future. He knew a lot about my life (my address, the school I went to) so I believed him. I've memorised everything he told me so I can repeat it back to myself in the future. He told me to stay true to myself, then he became urgent. `I need £15,000 in cash right now. The future is bleak and this is the only way you can help me.` I obliged. Later I realised this didn't make sense, I could have just put £15,000 into a trust fund and it would've been worth way more. That's when I realised I'd been scammed. That's right. My future self scammed me to teach me a lesson about trust. It made me who I am. Any day now I'll get this opportunity to time travel, but I must stick to the script or the timeline will be fractured. Can't wait to meet my younger self, and scam the hell out of the little shit.

There is one downside of remote work people never talk about: My employees cannot see my ass. I have a really good ass. When I'm strutting through the office, my employees are all checking it out. I don't see this happening but I can sense it. When someone sees my ass they subconsciously think `Wow. I better reply to my clients' e-mails quicker`. There is no better way to get someone to reply to e-mails. The ass is a very powerful status symbol in the workplace. The ass inspires people to be their best selves. The ass is motivation. HR can't seem to understand this, nor why I would send pictures of my ass in my e-mail signature or why I'm trying to get `Show Ass on Camera Thursday Zooms` to be a thing. There have been many lawsuits against me and my ass. My enemies fear its power. Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs: pay ➡ security ➡ love and belonging ➡  self-esteem ➡ self-actualisation ➡  ass

I HIRED a candidate over 50. You can't imagine the resistance I had to overcome. The HR manager was not impressed. She said he `will not fit into our culture`, `this man is 87 years old` and `he wandered into the office by accident while you were conducting interviews.` These were true facts. Most CEOs would say `you've got the wrong building.` I took a chance. Everyone is looking for 18 year olds with 20 years experience. Why not try 87 year olds with 0 years experience? Society has to change. We can no longer discriminate against candidates based on their age, experience, IT skills or the fact they didn't even intend to interview for the job in the first place. He has honestly been a terrible hire, with absolutely no interest in developing antivirus software and takes about 30 minutes to open Microsoft Word. He keeps talking about fighting in World War II even though he was only 2 years old when it started. But at least I tried it. I learned a valuable lesson: don't hire someone just because they walked into your building when they were looking for the bowling alley.

One of my employees almost died at work and it was the best thing that ever happened to the company. They fell into a vat of acid and were badly burned. It was a total wake-up call for me. It was a reminder that I had become complacent, keeping a vat of acid in the middle of the office. They tried to sue the company, claiming it was negligent to not put any safeguards around the vat of acid. Most CEOs would shirk responsibility, but I owned it. The vat of acid was my idea and mine alone. Sometimes you need a few setbacks to learn a valuable lesson and I learned mine that day, that there was no reason to have a vat of acid when you're a firm that sells insurance. I did everything in my power to make sure it never happened again. I removed the vat of acid. I listened. I learned. I stepped up 💪💪💪.

I pay my workers to have therapy. They get a big bonus if they agree to sign up to the therapist I've found. I figured this will benefit me and my company in the long run. Why? The therapist I chose isn't a therapist at all. He feeds me all their traumas and anxieties so I can manipulate them better. Steve? He hates conflict and is a big people pleaser. I make him work weekends every other week. Debra? Daddy issues. I give her the approval that a father would. She works 30% harder. Charles? Afraid of spiders. I put spider wallpaper in the toilets so he takes fewer bathroom breaks. If they ask if he's actually a therapist, he legally has to tell them, but none of them have, which is on them. Is this really a crime if they're also getting paid more and some therapy?

People have accused me of performatively reading intelligent books in public. I was reading Malcolm Gladwell's `Outliers` in a cafe, and a woman came up to me. She said, `You're not even reading that. It's upside down.` I was holding it upside down. `Oh you don't think I'm reading it?` I then read out three paragraphs from it while holding it the wrong way up. She looked sheepish and embarrassed, and one man from a nearby table applauded (the whole cafe would've but it was a loud cafe and we weren't shouting the exchange.) I've spent the last 5 years training this skill because reading things the right way up was no longer a challenge for me. I now sit and read like this in public to see who is close minded and who is open to new ideas. Reading normally is boring and for conventionals. Reading upside down is for true `Outliers.`

`Help. I've fallen over, can you give up your weekend to come over and make me a hot stew?` You receive this text from an elderly relative - what do you do? Do you complain that's not part of your contract, or that weekend is meant to be a time of rest? No, you show up. Then why is it different when you receive a text from me, your boss, asking you to give up your weekend to come into work and make me a hot stew? Why are you okay with your grandmother pinching your cheeks and commenting on how big you've grown, but not when I do it? Why won't you love me, dress me, bathe me, like your grammy? Bosses are the elders of society and deserve tender love and care too. If you would treat them differently than your own grandmother then you are a hypocrite.

This 3 year old child I met on the bus was exhibiting toxic masculinity. He was: 🚩 not respecting women (not listening to his mother) 🚩taking up space and manspreading (using a whole seat when he is tiny) 🚩 refusing to recognise his privilege and redistribute his wealth (refusing to give up his seat to me) 🚩 unnecessarily stubborn in a little shit way (still didn't give up his seat) 🚩 physically violent (started hitting me when I tried to move him off his seat) 🚩 bad at taking no for an answer (as in `no you can't have your seat back`) 🚩 very emotionally coercive (cried to his mother and the bus driver) 🚩used his status as a powerful male against me (got me thrown off the bus) Truly a sign we are still living in a patriarchy. Men would rather throw a tantrum about giving up their seat than go to therapy.

I initially rejected a candidate's CV twice. However, when he applied a third time, I decided to invite him for an interview. We offered him a role immediately after the interview. Why? Because I realised he was the brother to a mega famous pop star. Now, a year later, he's terrible at his job and costing the business a lot with his mistakes. But I get a VIP booth at his sister's concerts. Sometimes money and profit isn't everything. Status is also important.

Sorry but kissing an alien is not a big deal. I would kiss this alien that Sabrina Carpenter kissed in a heartbeat. Not at all unique or interesting. Making a business deal with an alien, however? Much more impressive. And I think I can do it. One day an alien will come to Earth seeking to destroy us. I will however sit down with that alien and formulate a business plan, where we can both mutually benefit. The alien would reconsider its decision to annihilate us and instead enter a corporate merger, uniting against our common enemy: the consumers. Sometimes business can feel like you're dealing with an alien but remember that there is one universal currency...fat stacks. I would then kiss the alien, like I do in all my business meetings.

I have recently come under fire for having a 100% male upper management team. Thank you for raising this important issue. As a very successful CEO with a lot of followers, I am committed to hiring the best employees for certain jobs, regardless of gender. It just so happens that these are all men who are my best friends from university. The reality is that certain professions naturally have gender imbalances. For example, there are more CEOs called John than there are women. My conclusion is that there must be something particularly success-oriented about the name John, so I have hired a lot of people called John. It just so happens that these are all men who also went on my stag do. While I fully support the push for greater diversity in the workplace, the current ratio of male to female persons with the name John makes this very difficult. And hiring people named John is something I'll never compromise on. It's important to note that I am a very successful CEO and good looking. Criticising me is very easy if you are not any of these things. We should instead point fingers at all the women who refuse to be called John. Targeting me who is part of the solution, not the problem, is counterproductive, as I will never change.

`Explain this gap in your CV.` You might think this is a gauche question for me to ask a potential hire, but it is something I need to know. Why? Why should I care? Because I need to know if you were using that period to go back in time to kill JFK. I've studied the footage. The only way JFK could've been killed was by a second gunman (or gunwoman) that must have used a time machine. Why is this important for selling antivirus software? Because time travelling to kill JFK shows: - 💡resourcefulness - 💡determination - 💡ability to follow things through - 💡ability to meet deadlines - 💡a strong belief that the timeline is what we make of it These are all qualities I value in an employee and specifically only met if you were on the grassy knoll killing JFK. So please, in the two years between your Masters in Creative Writing and being an accountant at KPMG, were you killing JFK?

Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs is missing an important part of the equation. Meet Bob. Bob is a hardworking guy who has all his needs fulfilled. However one day I saw him take 8 extra minutes for lunch. He had some calamari squid and I decided this was unacceptable. The next day I told him to meet in the basement where he was confronted in the dark by the Squid King brandishing 8 machetes (it was me in a squid costume.) He was frightened out of his mind and I told him he must submit to the Squid King and never be late back from lunch again. He never was. Now, the legend of the Squid King permeates through my office, and everyone is a devoted follower of the Squid Doctrine. That's what Maslow failed to include in his model: cults. What monstrous deity have you invented to keep your workers in check?

My employee RESIGNED. She left to start her own business. This is what I told her. `Thank you for all your wonderful contributions. It's sad to see you go, but I wish you every bit of success in your new ventures. I hope you keep on moving forward and never ever slow down.` I then went out into the parking lot and cut the brake lines in her car. She will certainly never slow down now.

My 8 year old son fell off his bike and grazed his knee. I rushed to my first aid kit but before I gave out a plaster, I asked `how are you going to pay for it?` He was screaming in pain and saying he already spent his pocket money for the week. `That wasn't very smart was it? What happens if you have an accident you're not prepared for?` I told him he might have to give back his bike to pay for the plaster and he screamed about how unfair that was. Sorry, the business world is unfair. I could see he learned his lesson so I agreed to give him the plaster this time for free but he now had a choice. He could either invest 30% of his pocket money every week to pay for future medical emergencies, or the next time he suffers an accident he'd have to give up his whole bike. He took the first option. And that is how I sold my 8 year old son health insurance.

I pretended to steal my friend's 6 year old son's nose. I put my thumb between my fingers and said `got your nose.` `That's not my nose. It's clearly just your thumb. Do you think I'm stupid?` he said. I could tell he was already a smart critical thinker, so I hatched a plan. I got one of my business contacts who worked in prosthetics to build a realistic looking nose, and bought a few batches of fake blood. Next time I saw him he was cocky. `Are you going to pull another stupid fake nose trick on me again?` This time I pretended to yank very hard, and pull his nose off his face. I presented him with the very realistic nose covered in blood. He began screaming and crying. His parents came rushing in, asking what the hell I did. What I did was I taught this kid an incredibly important lesson: child or not, no one ever gets the upper hand on Ken Cheng.

I was humiliated by a comedian on stage last night. I was sitting on the front row of a comedy gig and the comedian started making fun of me just because I was yelling things out during his routine and ruining his punchlines. I thought the crowd would be on my side because I make more money and was better dressed than he was. However, when I told the comedian that my watch costs more than his house, the crowd booed me? Is this what society has become? You are booed at simply for being a success? I can't help that I'm rich. I was simply born this way. Comedy used to mean something, back when it used to aim itself at the establishment, instead of hard-working multimillionaires who want expensive watches. I felt so alone in that comedy gig, without a friend in the world. But I then remembered the most important thing: I am rich. I can buy friends.

An employee asked me if he can WORK from HOME. Here's what I said. `Yes. Absolutely. I'm so glad you suggested this because you are wasting time on your commute. You can start right now.` He was elated and started packing things up to leave. Me: `where are you going?` Him: `you said I could work from home.` That's when I told him to come with me to the 14th floor. I led him to a converted storage closet with a single bed and a sink. This was his new home. `Sorry but you live here now. Your verbal contract is binding. Also I'll be expecting your £750 rent payment at the end of the month.` Never, ever ask me if you can work from home.

I was at a party last night in a fancy venue and there were all sorts of free canapés. It was time to maximise. Firstly I stood in the thoroughfare by the kitchen to have the first right of refusal on anything they brought out. An old colleague and the godfather of my first child, Rodney, came up to talk to me - I'd not seen him in person in 5 years because of the pandemic. However, I did not register a word he said because I was too busy focussing on the canapés. He kept trying to usher me over to meet his new daughter, but I felt sceptical. Was he trying to lead me away from the thoroughfare? So his wife can stand guard and hoover up supplies for his recently upsized family? I stood my ground and told him I did not want to meet his boring daughter. He walked away and the thoroughfare was safe once again. Soon they brought out several samosas and goujons (my fav) and I decided to take multiple of each for my `family` (I was there alone). The waiters could not stop me and even if they tried, I would quote my rights as a consumer under contract law. Once I had pocketed about 6 goujons, 8 skewers, 12 arancini balls, 8 samosas and 4 sausage rolls, I went to collect my bag in which I had brought two boxes of tupperware. I quickly did an Irish goodbye as my mission was accomplished. I hope Rodney is well, I would love to have caught up with him properly.

One of my employees, Catherine, was 1 hour late for work the other day and most bosses would fire them right there. I, however, had different plans. I decided to make her think she was a ghost. Before she arrived, I ordered every single person in the office to ignore her and treat her as invisible. There is an automatic door into the office that I decided to reprogram to no longer detect her. This turned out to be impossible but I could make it manually operated from my office, so I personally watched it until she arrived and made sure she had to tailgate other people in. When she arrived at her cubicle it was covered by police do-not-cross tape and there was a massive blood stain on the carpet, as if she had died there. I also hired a creepy child (my head of HR's nephew) to also pretend to be a ghost that was the only person to see her and say things like `where is my mommy?` Eventually we got bored around lunchtime so started talking to her again. She was suitably creeped out by the whole thing and was never late again. She eventually quit, not because of this but because the bloodstain in her office proved impossible to get out. Still, I hope she learned something from this.
