I bought a burial spot for my first startup company. When my first company was declared bankrupt, I held a funeral procession for it and placed an effegy of it into a casket, which got lowered into the ground. Very few people came to this. Every year now I visit the grave to leave flowers and tell it how much it taught me about business. This year there was an elderly woman also visiting her husband's grave, whom she was married to for 50 years. Her story was touching and all, but her husband was just one man, whereas my company employed 12 people and in a way, they all died when the company went under. When I told her about my lost loved one, she burst into tears. `Losing Ernest was hard but it is nothing compared to what you and the world lost when Cartocopies folded. You are very brave.` She got it in a way no one else did. It's a shame people don't value the lives of companies as much as actual humans, just because they don't have sentience, feelings or any physical form. RIP Cartocopies Jun 31st 2008 - Sep 1st 2009

Several years ago a previous girlfriend caught me using Tinder on my phone and was very mad. She had no right to be. This is equivalent to looking at a job advert while you're currently employed. If an employer told you that you can't do that, that would be illegal. If they checked your phone like she did, that's a breach of my privacy. She said she was trying to check the weather and saw the notification which is several nude photos. I quoted that any evidence obtained unlawfully is inadmissable in court. She said `THIS is inadmissable in court` and threw my phone out the window, which I found immature. You are legally allowed to interview for other companies even if you have a perfectly good job, just like I am legally allowed to solicit buttpics even if I have a perfectly good butt at home. Ultimately a relationship is a lot like business in which you have to adhere to the explicit terms of the contract and the law. Rachel could not understand this, like a toxic business partner. What happened to the buttpics? Reader, I married her.

My wife made me sleep in the car for a week. It taught me a lot about resilience, culpability and imperfection. We had a huge argument because I accidentally locked her out of the house by leaving the keys in the front door. She banged on the door for hours but I was playing Call of Duty with headphones in. When she eventually climbed through the slightly open kitchen window, she was livid. I understood her anger even though there was nothing anyone could have done to avoid this. Everyone makes mistakes in business and in marriage. She seemed unable to accept this. I told her `worst comes to worst, you could've slept in the car.` My solutions based  mindset seemed to make her more angry. She said sleeping in the car is horrific and I replied that it isn't, and I could do it for a whole week if I had to, so that's what I did. When I came back, she was still angry even though a) I showed her I was able to accept penance and b) I was completely right about the car thing. Sometimes, like in business, a relationship just doesn't see eye to eye. It's nobody's fault. I am probably getting a divorce. But that's life. Nobody is perfect.

I get a lot of requests for feet pics on this website. It makes sense. I'm a top 10% percentile attractive top 1% percentile successful CEO. I have hundreds of messages in my inbox, some asking for them for free and some offering between £10-£500. One day I agreed to send one. Why not? Is selling feet pics any different to selling antivirus software? Amy was elated. After I got over the initial weirdness, it felt good, knowing I've made one person happy. Months later, I'm interviewing for a new position at another company. Who turns up? Why it's Amy. She takes one look at my shoes, licks her lips and hires me. Strange coincidence huh? Not really, I've been looking to work there ever since I connected with her way before she messaged me. When life hands you lemons, take pictures of your feet. Feet pics are like Christmas presents. Only ever give them to people that can enhance your career.

Mike was planning to propose to Jenny just before end of play last Friday in the office. They met 4 years ago working here when their desks were opposite each other and their love blossomed. He asked me to help out - he wanted elaborate music, and loads of fanfare, with a  big banner coming down from the ceiling. I agreed. When it came to 4:45pm, he got down on one knee to ask the question and she seemed so excited. Then the banner dropped: it had a massive expletive on it. The music played was inappropriate. Everything was botched. I purposely sabotaged it, to teach them a lesson about business. 1) you always have to be prepared for things to go wrong in the workplace 2) you should have waited until after end of play instead of proposing on my company time. I don't pay you to propose, Mike.

Sometimes at the end of a meeting at work, it's hard to tell when you should lean in for a kiss. I find business meetings very intimate and intense, whether it's a job interview, a performance review or an external client. This naturally leads to wanting to kiss. However, I know too well that leaning in and making them feel uncomfortable is disastrous. That's why I've invented the `I Don't Want To Be Kissed` Badge. There's a tray at the front desk that people can take them from and wear throughout the day to avoid me trying to kiss them. This should make them feel 100% safe at work. Since I introduced them, almost every single employee has started using them, especially the women. That's when you know it was a good idea. Thanks to this one simple trick, not a single person has been kissed in my office that didn't want to be. Workplace sexual harassers hate me.

How do you deal with an employee who is too into astrology? Katie who works under me is obsessed with horoscopes, checking them daily on a new hip website, demureastrobrat.com . One day I asked her to work on Saturday, but her horoscope told her to `have a light weekend for a special surprise`, so she refused. I told her she can't refuse on that basis, but she said I'm not allowed to discriminate based on beliefs and threatened to sue me. Checkmate for her, or was it? That's when I did what no one would ever think of: I bought up demureastrobrat.com . Knowing she was a Gemini (courtesy of our HR department), I personally wrote the Gemini horroscopes for several weeks. They included things like `If you want to meet a special man, you better work late tonight` `Promotions only bring despair; taking a paycut will bring you inner peace.` `In order to find pure happiness, you must look inside yourself and sign up to a Microsoft Access course` Eventually, demureastrobrat.com ran out of money and had to shut down, and it left a huge financial hole in my assets. But it was worth it though, it was worth it to win. I won, Katie.

How do you fairly slice a cake? It was Martha's birthday in the office and someone brought a cake. However, if we did it equally between everyone, all 45 of us would get a tiny amount. I brainstormed. I considered that we do it by salary, but this seemed unfair as I would get the most cake. That's when it hit me: we should do it by how much people had contributed to the cake eating process itself. Sean got 25% for baking the cake. Sally got 12.5% for going to the kitchen to get the knife. Ben got 12.5% for transporting the cake to the office. And I got 50% for taking charge of the distribution process, R&Ding how we could cut the cake, and managing everyone. Marsha got absolutely nothing as she didn't even know about the cake's existence until it was in front of her. Without me stepping in and leading the situation, everyone would've been sitting around not eating cake. Managers are the real heroes of any process.

I caught a member of my Sales team masturbating at work. I promoted him on the spot. Here's why. I was in the bathroom cubicle next to him and could hear him. Instead of being angry, I was curious so I kicked open the cubicle door and asked `hey buddy, what turned you on today?` He was shocked at first but then admitted `I just made a big sale and it made me feel good.` This is the pure passion I want from every employee of mine to feel for work, so I made him my Deputy Head of Sales (the previous one seemed to never masturbate at work at all.) He was elated at this news. I gave him a pat on the back and said `ejaculate away, sir.` Since then I've been keenly watching who takes bathroom breaks. If your job isn't turning you on at least once a week, why are you even working?

I sometimes play Werewolf with my co-workers. 2 werewolves, 5 villagers. The werewolves have to avoid detection while the villagers must find the werewolves. I came up with an unbeatable strategy. The werewolf is trying to act as a villager, so I immediately come out and say I am a werewolf when I'm a villager, because a werewolf would never do that. It is a brilliant strategy that follows foolproof logic, even though everyone always executes me for doing this because they are logicless idiots. I've been applying this practice to the business world. For example, I once interviewed a candidate and they said `I am terrible at my job.` I hired him on the spot. Why? Someone terrible at their job would be lying about being good at their job, so I surmised they must be good at their job. Perfect logic. He did turn out to be terrible at his job though and I fired him after 3 months for leaking all our customers' passwords, but the logic itself was still sound. You miss 100% of the terrible candidates you don't hire.

nobody will remember: - your salary people will remember: - that your break room has an air hockey table This is why I have refused to raise my employees' salaries for 5 years but I did install an air hockey table in the break room in September 2022

The story about Disney not allowing someone to sue them because they snuck a clause into the Disney Plus 1 month free trial terms and agreements is nothing new. I have been doing this as an employer and landlord for years. For example I rent a small two bedroom apartment in the centre of town to a couple, Steve and Jen. I put into the tenancy agreement that I'm allowed to use the second bedroom at any point if I'm tired or hungry. I also snuck in that if I do use it, Steve must tuck me in at night with a storybook of my choice. Furthermore, if I ever have a nightmare (which is often), I'm also allowed to knock on their door and ask if I can sleep with them that night. I do this 2 nights a week. Steve & Jen are livid, but they are bound by contract law. i take zero pleasure in doing this and hopefully this will be an important lesson: Always read the fine print, because there might be some crazy people out there looking to take advantage.

I was flying on a plane yesterday and someone collapsed. A cabin crew member asked, `Is there a doctor on the plane?!` I said yes. I have no medical experience. Here's why I did: As a CEO, you know that if your business is struggling, the worst thing you can do is cause a panic. For years, my previous company was in massive debt but it was important for the workers to stay positive, so I told them nothing. The same is true on a plane: plane morale is more important than anything, even one man's health. Plus, there was a small chance once I got to look at him, my instincts would kick in and I'd be able to help him. When I had a look, nothing was coming to me, but everyone was watching me. I gave them all a thumbs up and the plane cheered. That company in debt eventually collapsed, but my workers were optimistic until the end, and that's what matters. I hope the man eventually got the help he needed.

I was hiring for a very integral position at my company. I was down to only two candidates. They were equally qualified, both gave equally good interviews. It was impossible to decide between them. That's when I had a genius idea and called both back in. I decided to smell them. I can deduce a lot from smelling someone - it's like a sixth sense to me. For example, when I sniffed the first candidate, I got a sense he lived in an affluent neighborhood. His coffee breath smelled like the upmarket stuff rather than a chain, and there was a strong artisan bakery scent. There was a whiff of grease oil so I knew he didn't mind getting his hands dirty. He smelled good at his job. I then brought in the second candidate. When I leaned in to smell him, he freaked out. He screamed `what are you doing` and had to leave. I knew immediately he wasn't right for this position. What a shame, but sometimes you just know it's not going to work. We hired the first candidate. In business, in order to get the job you want, you need to be willing to be smelled.

`You're fired.` One of the most devastating words to receive from your boss. In my first job as manager, I had to tell Jonathan he was fired for turning up to work high on cocaine. However, he pulled out a Uno Reverse card and said `Uno Reverse.` `Shit,` I thought. `I'm fired now.` This was the worst way this could've gone. But then I remembered: we weren't playing Uno. However, I briefly felt exactly what it would be like to get fired. The pain. The confusion. The uncertainty. I couldn't do that to Jonathan, especially as he was creative enough to try the Uno play. So I rehired him. I later explained what happened to MY bosses and guess what? They fired me. So Jonathan's reverse card did work in the end. Guess we were playing Uno after all.

My 12 year old daughter got diagnosed with ADHD and I couldn't be prouder of her, but not for the reason you think. She said to me `Dad, I don't think I have ADHD but I think I can get a diagnosis in 2 years by studying for the test.` Me: `No, impossible, they're trained professionals.` Her: `Oh so you don't think I can achieve anything I want by working hard enough?` Me: `I guess not.` Her: `I guess there's no point me studying for my GCSEs then.` She had me there. So I let her try this. She researched different places to take the rest and maximised her chances by studying famous people with ADHD like Justin Timberlake and Bart Simpson. Fast forward two years and she's achieved the impossible, and she sells the ADHD meds she's prescribed on the internet to make a tidy profit too. If you work hard enough, anything is achievable.

An ambulance skipped past me while I was stuck in traffic and late for work. I can accept this. What I can't accept is that I'm not also allowed to do the same as a CEO. Sure, the ambulance might save lives. But my work definitely does too. I sell a very important product (bank security software) that protects people's livelihoods I also hire and employ hundreds, who would not be able to put food on the table if I didn't. Ambulances also indiscriminate. They have to save whoever calls them up, even if they're a murderer or bad at their job. I get to choose who I hire. The ambulance can only save one life. My company which affects millions, saves many. Which is why I have no problem skipping traffic. Every second a CEO is not at work, people die.

Look at this exchange: `Darling can you do the dishes tonight?` `No, unless you pay me overtime as it's a Sunday and in the evening.` Pretty crazy thing to say right? Now replace `dishes` with `come into the office and work on next week's case`. No longer crazy apparently, according to employment law. Why? We should treat the two situations the exact same. Sometimes your company is more like a family than an office. Sometimes being in a loving supportive family requires hard sacrifices. And sometimes hard sacrifices means someone stepping up and working Sunday evening without being a little bitch about overtime. If I don't pay my wife overtime to do the dishes, why should I pay you, an employee who I don't love half as much and is nowhere near as sexy? Make it make sense.

We need to talk about ageism in the workplace. Ageism is just like racism or sexism, but for old people. However I've found it works both ways, with young ages too. For example, I have just hired a 13 year old as the head of social media at my company. Many people were outraged, saying he is underqualified for this role and I only hired him because he is my son (which he is.) THAT is ageism. They wouldn't be saying that if he was 22, and I know this because no one complained when I hired my 22 year old son. Many are calling this hire `inappropriate`, `unlawful` and `child labour`. I just shake my head in dismay at it all. It is sad to see so many of my own employees succumb to the scourge of ageism and never question it.

Let me tell you about the Kraken. It is that one thing we want to slay in our lives and our careers. For some, it's a promotion. Others, it is being published in an academic journal. Everyone has their own personal Kraken. What's mine? Mine is the actual Kraken. Every day I think about hunting and killing the actual Kraken. When I'm looking at my profit margins, I'm thinking `have I amassed enough funds to buy a large sea vessel to embark on my journey to find the Kraken?` Whenever I'm hiring, I'm thinking `do you have what it takes to take on the Kraken?` When I'm in any meeting with the board of directors, my head is saying `Kraken Kraken Kraken Kraken Kraken Kraken Kraken Kraken.` All my life now is eat, sleep and Kraken. It's important to have goals. Mine is Kraken. What's your Kraken in business?

Business has taught me how to speak to women very clearly using terms that cant possibly hurt their feelings. For example I was seeing someone who was more interested in me than I was in her, and it was time to end things. Here's what I said to her: `Some of my friends have raised concerns with your conduct and we have spoken about them before. Unfortunately although I have seen some changes needed to keep you on board, our relationship needs to be brought in line with my other female friends. I spoke to my parents and we agreed I just don't have the bandwidth to take on another girlfriend right now. You of course have a chance to appeal this decision. Take some time to think about this and we can circle back in 4-6 weeks. Please keep an official record of this email to avoid any legal confusion in the future.` She never appealed the decision.

Going into liquidation can feel bad, but it can be an amazing opportunity. I was working as a contractor for a company that I did several months work for and hadn't paid me. That company went into liquidation and I didn't get a penny, even though they still paid themselves and others. That's when I realised: liquidation frees you from any obligations, it is a blessing not a curse. For example, my friend, Carl, lent me £2000 to cover my dental costs, or did they? What they didn't realise was they were lending it to my limited liability company, Edgesoft, which was having financial difficulty and is now in liquidation. Bye bye £2,000. Another friend, Samantha, drove me to the airport a few months ago and wanted me to drive them this month in return. No, they really drove TrueData employee to the airport, which is now in liquidation. No ride for you, Sam. I was dogsitting for my neighbour while they were away in Malta, or was I? It was Rewind Industries looking after their dog. Sorry, liquidation - dog is mine now. Liquidation can get you out of all sorts of situations. I now have 12 companies on the verge of financial ruin for these kind of scrapes. Be like water, be liquid.

I once saved a mother with an unborn child from a burning building. She was so grateful for my help that she agreed to name her child after me. I said `name her Novatas` which was the name of my first company. She did. 21 years later, the daughter became a very successful travel influencer, with a large following, and got in contact to thank me for saving her life. I sued her for copyright infringement. I had trademarked the name Novatas way back when before her birth and she had been using it for her branding. Legally I was entitled to a lot of her revenue because her mother was silly enough to fall for this trick. You enter the game as soon as you're born and you can't miss a day playing it.

Weddings are impressive things. It's so rare that two people can get along so well that they commit to working together as one team forever. Why then, do we not celebrate corporate mergers the same way? Why did Exxon and Mobile gather in a church and declare their vows to be true to each other? Why didn't Penguin and Random House stand in front of a priest and enshrine their partnership under God? Why didn't AT&T and Time Warner go on holiday together after? Perhaps because this extra pageantry is good short term, but doesn't provide long term partnership success. Hence why these big companies have stayed together and I've had many divorces. That's why I will conduct my next wedding like a corporate merger. We will both bring our closest advisors and hash out the terms of our marriage over a long business table in a formal productive and legally robust way. Everyone will be wearing suits, including the women, which is more business appropriate and less sexist. Then, it will end with a handshake, not a kiss. True love isn't extravagant, it's professional. Weddings are impressive things, but corporate mergers are incredible.

I've started a side job running corporate gigs for other companies. Have you heard of Mafia? Werewolf? The Traitors? I host games of that for their teams. I ran one for the #2 Password Manager service in the world. In the games, people truly reveal themselves, and I let them. I encourage things to get truly personal to reach maximum conflict. For example, I made the two co-founders the werewolves, but instead of showing a card that said `you are a werewolf`, I also showed Paul a card that said `Jeff (the other  werewolf) is sleeping with your wife.` to see what happened. It turned out Jeff had been sleeping with his wife. The two had a massive row with each other and actually started a physical fight, and everyone knew they were the werewolves. It's crazy how silly little games can make us behave sometimes. Sufficed to say, that company fell apart and is no longer the #2 Password Manager in the world now. Who is? My company. Your side hustle is also your main hustle. (Do book me for your corporate gigs, I'm an excellent games master.)

I find trade unions very triggering. They remind me of school bullies, forming a big group and ganging up on one defenceless kid. When my employees went on strike, it felt like being 11 again. Loads of physically intimidating older boys forming a circle around me asking for my lunch money. They used to pick me because they feared my intelligence and success in lessons. Now it's my success in business as the CEO. It's the same insecurity, the same naked rage. Back then, I could tell the teacher and they would intervene. Now, the teacher (mediators, the law) is always on the bullies' side. When the bullies win, everyone cheers them on on social media. No one cheers on the scared, traumatised CEO who just got their money taken. We need that to change. We need justice.

`You are really good at business, but you are too f***ing sexy.` I have been told this all the time and it has to stop. I can't help that making smart business decisions is a very sexually charged quality. It is frustrating to be ogled at while in the midst of a corporate merger, just because I am dressed smart and project success. This is a problem me and several CEOs face, and it's about time we start to speak out about it. I get so many advances from my employees all the time and it is a classic case of `inverse abuse of power.` There's nothing I can do but accept the millions of compliments, it's a curse that haunts me to my core.

When Harry Met Sally poses the eternal question `can women and men ever be friends?` Well, I'd like to ask can a boss and his employee ever be friends? The new intern Jonathan seems to think no. I've invited him to dinner several times, and I keep texting him really good memes from a website called 9gag and he doesn't seem to reply. This hurt my feelings. I got a reply from Jonathan that evening. Guess who's finally coming to dinner?

There were hundreds of ants in my kitchen. When one died it released a toxin that signalled the rest to come. This was very annoying, but also an example of a perfect workforce. I wish my employees would send themselves to death en masse simply to gather more resources (or sell more insurance). I sometimes dream that I am an Ant Queen. I picture that my business is one hive mind. My employees do everything I say without question or consultation, and it is my sole responsibility to sexually reproduce more workers for my company. Truly the perfect CEO. I have bought a massive Queen ant costume that I sit in sometimes. What other examples in nature are there of a really good business model?

Do you believe that there is a Chosen One? I've seen films like The Matrix where there is a prophecy of someone so powerful they will save the world. I similarly believe there is a `Chosen One` of Social Media Marketing, who can save the world of physical media. They are someone so gifted they can write social media posts for 72 hours straight without getting tired or becoming derivative. This is why I push all my Social Media Managers to the absolute limit, with no breaks or sleep. Several have passed out, with one even needing to be sent to hospital. I thought I had found them, a true natural talent, but they turned out to just have ADHD and the ability to hyperfocus. After 36 hours they ended up in a psych ward. It'll all be worth it when I find The One. Finding true brilliance takes hard work, patience, and a few employees ending up in the psych ward.

I was about to have a zoom meeting at home when my 5 year old asked me what it was about. I told him it was important as I was about to fire an employee. `But Dad, why is that such a hard thing to do?` He didn't understand, so it was time for an important learning experience. I showed him my script I had written out. As soon as I loaded up the zoom call with Paul, I told him he had to read out my script (luckily he has the reading age of a 9 year old). At first he was excited. He did well at the pleasantries - asking about Paul's wife and homebrewed beer - but when it came to the actual firing, he stumbled. He turned to me and protested `why do we have to fire Paul?! He has such kind eyes!` Paul gasped. `I'm...getting fired?` He started to break down, crying and screaming though stopping short of obscenities for my son's sake (great guy, Paul). My son said he couldn't watch but I said he MUST, because he caused this. Eventually Paul ended the zoom call himself and my son was left shivering.  He was ready to be a CEO. Coddled kids who are shielded from life's stresses grow up to be nervous, victims. Kids who are exposed to uncomfortable truths early grow up to become strong leaders who definitely never need therapy. My 5 year old became a man today.

Poor friends: - Sport - Celeb goss - Microwave meals - Michael Bay movies - Hanging at the local quarry Rich friends: - Self-improvement - Psychology - Who will protect the Amulet - Brene Brown - What happens if the Amulet is destroyed and the Gorgon returns - How will we defeat the Gorgon - What moral values must we sacrifice to ensure the Gorgon does not reach the Ether Realm - David Foster Wallace

My friend organised a bowling trip for their partner's birthday this weekend. The organiser asked people to pay £15 each upfront for the cost of booking. I told him I didnt enjoy bowling so will just come for drinks afterwards. `It's okay don't worry about it, you can just come watch,` he said, so I did. When I arrived they felt bad for me not taking part and insisted I join a team. I said I don't know if I'd enjoy it and they were shocked. Them: `You've never gone bowling before?` Me: `no.` Them: `You have to give it a go! Me: `But I didn't pay the booking charge.` Them: `Don't worry about it, I'd rather you have a new experience.` I reluctantly agreed, and ended up bowling for a couple hours and had an amazing time. I even got two strikes. The truth: I actually love bowling. I've bowled a hundred times before. And if they knew that, I wouldn't have got to do it for free. Never show people your cards while a deal is still being made, even when it comes to your friends. The negotiation doesn't end on Friday afternoon. hashtag # negotiation

Is there any point posting on LinkedIn on a Saturday? Yes. If an employee likes my post on the weekend, I know they're still thinking about work. That shows immense skill and dedication. Going on LinkedIn on the weekend just makes you better than everyone else. You're the elite. The top 15%. There should be a Mensa for people who check LinkedIn on Saturdays. Wait, there is. It's right here right now. And if you can see this post, you're in the club. Welcome, the 15%.

Here is one simple trick I learned that has allowed me to ace any job interview: LISTEN TO THE ORB 5 years ago I discovered a mysterious black orb the size of a bowling ball washed up on Hunstanton beach. Since then it has spoken to me in times of crisis. Words of advice. `Turn left here` `don't eat that leftover chicken` `buy Nvidia stock` I now take it to every job interview and have it in my rucksack while they ask me questions. `My strengths and weaknesses?` I ask while I stall for time to consult the orb. `Well obviously my ability to always adapt to the situation perfectly, thanks to my Orb` `Your what-` `My instincts. Thanks to my instincts` Luckily only I can hear the orb. This amazing life hack has allowed me to succeed in business, and it only comes at a deadly price. What other great tips do you have for making sure you get the job?

Happy Pride Month! 🌈 🌈 🌈 Oh, Pride Month is already over, you say? Not for me. LGBTQ+ Pride is important to me every month. Now, a lot of companies have been accused of virtue signalling with empty gestures during Pride, but I can assure you we are following through, that's why: - we put up Rainbow flags around the office - I have changed my desktop wallpaper to Heartstopper - LGBTQ+ employees get optional Fridays off (unpaid) - I've started watching RuPaul's Drag Race to understand the culture - LGBTQ+ customers get 10% off our Antivirus software (if they can prove they are LGBTQ+) - I stop employees randomly at their desk to yell `PRIDE!` - LGBTQ+ employees get selected items of food for free in the café (bananas, ketchup sachets, salt) - An LGBTQ+ employee will get promoted regardless of experience or job performance - I have stopped calling people `gay` as an insult - I have committed to hiring an LGBTQ+ employee by 2026 (we don't have any yet) There's no way you can read all that and not think I'm a committed ally boss. Send any proof pics to our Sales team when you check out. Happy Pride! And most importantly, stay virus-free with our latest product. ✨

Things I'm sick of hearing from my employees: - Can I leave early today - I'll be late in the morning - Project Beast will devour us all - My child is sick, can I rush off - We need a better contingency plan in case Project Beast backfires - Is it okay if I take Friday off? - Help, help someone released Project Beast from its cage - I'm going to be late back from lunch, I've got some things to sort. - We didn't plan for this! We didn't plan for this! - I need more time on my deadline - We were fools. Fools to think we could control nature. We meddled with things we could not possibly understand. Now, Simon from HR is dead.

I had a tooth removed yesterday. It hurt like hell. It made me think. Your teeth are like your employees. Ideally you'd have a perfect set, and you wouldn't have to remove any of them. Because I am a good guy, I tried to hold onto this tooth as long as I could but it just wasn't worth it. Sometimes, a tooth is damaged, and underperforming. Sometimes it's infected. Sometimes, it is sticking out and looks really ugly. That's why I had to fire Joel last month, because he was sticking out and really ugly. He was ruining photos and just had to go. Just like teeth, a team is only as strong as it's ugliest tooth, and Joel really was an ugly, ugly tooth. He was so damn ugly. It hurt like hell to lose him, but sometimes you just have to let the ugly ones go. Also, being high on drugs helped.

The 4 day working week is a big scam being propagated to make people spend more money at M&M World. Think about it. We can and do only go there on weekend, where they make most of their revenue. Who stands to benefit most from a whole extra day that I'm able to shop at M&M World? That's right, M&M world. It's so obvious. If I let Adam go down to a 4 day week so he can `see his kids more`, I bet I know where I'll find him. Yep, M&M World. It's fine to spend your whole Saturday and Sunday there, scoffing down M&Ms like a pig all day, but Monday as well? That's insanely unhealthy. Everyone pushing for the 3 day weekend is in the pocket of Big M&M World. Push back.

The football mens team has never won the Euros yet the Lionesses won it as recently as last year. This made me think. I fired every man at my company today. Planning to replace them with an all-female team. It's a bold move some would call `sexist` and others will call `illegal.` But the England results speak for themselves. Every woman is better than every man at everything. It'll just be 200 women and me, the Sarina Wiegman of the Insurance Industry. This is what feminism looks like.

Sad to see our humble England team lose in the hashtag # Euro2024 finals last night and a lot of blame has been put squarely on the manager, Gareth Southgate. Let me tell you, it is NEVER the manager's fault. England lost for one reason alone: The players did not invest enough money crypto. I went to Phil Foden and offered him a great deal on my new cryptocurrency. He outright refused. I said how about this: if I can do more keepie-uppies than you, you must invest in my crypto. Not only did I do more keepie-uppies, I was still going for 15 minutes after him, and he begged me to stop because he was bored and wanted to get an ice lolly. `Okay,` I said, `now you have to get some of my new coin.` He said `sorry I have to go to practice` and just left. I never heard from him again. Had he invested in my coin, he would've made 20x his money back and had more confidence in the match last night. The fault of any football match loss rests squarely on the football employees. If a manager ever made a mistake, it is that they were too trusting of others to follow their vision. A chain is only as strong as its weakest link, and that link is never the CEO.

I met the Queen just before she died. She said I deserved a Knighthood for my services to the British Empire and she would make that happen right away. Unfortunately she passed not long after and I've finally come to accept that it probably  isn't going to happen. I guess the paperwork never went through, or she lied to my face. Now, any time an employee comes to me saying they `were promised a pay rise`, I just say `well I was promised a Knighthood.` The lesson is: never meet your heroes. And if you do, get everything they say in writing.

I have been looking for a job for 500 days now. The last rejection I got gave me this feedback: `You're an exceptional candidate, too exceptional. Being in an office with someone as intelligent and talented would make me feel like a small man. You are also incredibly handsome and I'm worried you would get more attention than me, and my wife would see you and leave me for you. You're also taller than me.` Sigh. Another one of these. Back to the drawing board.

Last week I was in a fish & chip shop and the man serving me was a millionaire. Yes that's right. He was an orthopedic surgeon for 30 years but now just serves fish and chips for 3 hours a night because it helps clear his mind. A fascinating way to live your life. I ordered cod and chips and thanked him for the impact he had on me. The next day I developed severe food poisoning from the fish so I anonymously called the health inspectors. They closed the place down for good. I guess that orthopedic surgeon will have plenty more time to clear his head now. Stay in your lane, doctor. Fish aren't feet. hashtag # FishArentFeet

Yes I am one of those mobile gaming `whales` you've heard about. I've spent £8,000 on an app called Monkey Farmer: Rise of Bobo. I'm level 134 with 7 billion Primate score. Maybe top 3 in the world. I spend 7 hours a day for the last 8 years keeping it up. Is it a waste of time? No. It has taught me so much about entrepreneurship. I would not be the businessman I am today without the hard work and research I put into my monkeys. It has also taught me valuable lessons, like when the game caused me to miss the birth of my third child, I learned the importance of not missing the birth of your child. I would have not known that. So yes, I may be a `whale`, but whales are also kings of the ocean, and in this case, the Monkey Farming industry. Consider that.

1989: Was born in the UK. Couldn't speak English. Was a baby 1990: Still a baby. No business degree at all 2024: Became CEO of a successful company Wow! What an amazing journey. Thank God I started with nothing - it just pushed me to do more.

For the last few years I have only asked one question during the hiring process. It's a simple one: `Do you like anime?` Anime can teach us a lot about business. One Piece is all about finding that USP so your business model stands out. Naruto is all about building your brand by enhancing a Ninja portfolio. Attack on Titan is a good lesson in protecting your assets with strong cybersecurity. There is not a single anime I've seen that hasn't made me a better CEO. Anyone who says they don't watch anime will never succeed in business and will be homeless in 5 years. Who agrees?

A lot of people yelled at me for firing one of my employees whose wife just had a baby. But the very next day, out of desperation, he went and bought £500 worth of lottery tickets. Guess what happened. He won nothing. However, on the way home from the shops a famous singer hit him with her car. He ended up in hospital with 8 broken bones and the singer paid him £2.5 million to keep things quiet. Had I not fired him, none of this would've ever happened. Now he is rich and has more time to spend with his child. I'm still waiting for my cut of the winnings.

You're not allowed to raise your voice anymore in 2024. Unless of course, you exclusively hire employees who have a fetish for being yelled at. That's why I expect all employees to list their fetishes on their CV. If they haven't, it's tricky, because you're not allowed to straight up ask people their fetishes in a job interview in 2024. Unless, of course, you exclusively hire people who have a fetish for oversharing. Which again would be solved by my point above. Put your fetishes on your CV if you want to stand out above the rest.

If a disgruntled employee is about to leave your company, steal one of their prized possessions from their desk before they pack their things up. I did this with William who was looking for a career change (because we fired him) and I was worried he'd sh*ttalk the company afterwards. I took a photo of him and his wife that was on his desk from his honeymoon. He asked if we had it and I said `it's possible it was misplaced`, which is true, as I had indeed misplaced it intentionally. I subtly hinted that if he agreed not to say bad things about our company, then I will `put in extra effort to find it`, which is again a true statement as I knew exactly where it was. He had no other choice so he reluctantly agreed. Did I do anything wrong? I was merely protecting my company's reputation. This story teaches a very important lesson in business: it's very hard to sue a company because they stole a photo of you and your wife.

One of my employees, Alan, was late this morning because they stayed up all night watching the General Election coverage. I called him into my office. He seemed very worried I'd fire him. `Name 3 constituencies that changed to Labour.` I said. He was anxious. He reeled off 6 or 7. `I'm going to pay you overtime for last night.` `Huh?` He was confused. `But I wasn't working.` `Taking part in and respecting the democratic process IS working. It's important to reward your employees for doing so.` He was so so grateful. When we left my office, another employee ran up to us with a post-it note. `What's that?` Alan asked. `Oh, while you were in there I conducted an office-wide poll on whether you should be fired. It's 67-33% in favour. Sorry Alan, you're going to have to leave.` He was devastated and yelled this was unfair until he was escorted out by security. So much for respecting the democratic process, huh? Everyone loves democracy until it doesn't go their way.

Just took my 6 year-old son to vote. He came out of the ballot box and asked `how come none of these names are CEOs or major corporations?` `Well, they're Politicians you see. They are elected to run the country.` My son: `I see, and how high are they on the World's All-Time Money List?` Me: `Errr...they're not very high.` My son: `What about in the UK?` Me: `Nope.` My son: `If they can't become the CEO of a very successful company then how can they be trusted with the keys to 10 Downing Street?` He had a point. He then said in a very loud voice, `which box for Jeff Bezos?` A cheer went up from the waiting voters.

Last weekend I was at a funeral and usually you might think it's a very inappropriate time to hand out your business card. However, even the grieving need good cloud computing services. At first, the widow wanted me to leave, but I made a case for what I was doing. I said: `I'm sorry for your loss. Life is very fleeting and can be taken away at any time, and so can important data on your physical hard drive. You may not be able to recover your husband, but you can recover lost data.` Even though this made her cry more, she conceded I had a point (not explicitly but I could tell she did). However, she still wanted me to leave. As I was being bundled into a car by her brother-in-law `Uncle Jerry`, I shouted `Exclusive mourners discount! 40% off if you use the code FUNERAL2024`. To most, this would be a very humiliating moment, but I checked our sales the next day, and lo and behold: two sales of our yearly subscription service. A sale is a sale, no matter how torn your suit gets. Always Be Closing.
SEO is very important in all aspects of naming, including naming your own child. Just ask my newborn son, `75% Off Taylor Swift Tickets Who Is The New James Bond Cheng`.

Last night's England game is exactly like how my first business started. It was extremely unprofitable for 99% of it's beginning period (much like in the match). I was making so many mistakes and we were hemorrhaging money (instead of goals). However, it doesn't matter how badly you perform for the duration as long as you can pull it back at the end, in the 90th minute. That's exactly how I did it, with a Bellingham style overhead kick that saved the business. (My father injected £5 million cash into the business) You are never truly out of the Euros as long as you have excellent skill.

I found out one of my employees, Dave, has the Super Duolingo Family Plan (a Premium Subscription service you can add other people to) and has a couple free slots to share on it. Immediately I held a meeting. I opened by saying how important it is that this office feels like a family. Dave seemed uninterested. He did not get the hint. The next day I held another meeting, this time focussing on how important it is to *understand each other*, despite any communication barriers. Nothing. The third day I called him in for a meeting and asked him, `if you were to name one father figure in your life, who would it be?` He said his actual father. He really wasn't picking up what I was putting down. I finally got sick of it and blurted out: `Add me to your Duolingo family plan or you're working this Saturday.` He was flummoxed - this was a complete surprise to him despite my many hints. He obliged, although he felt uneasy. Often, difficult conversations like this aren't easy. But still, mission accomplished. Direct communication is very important in the workplace.
I have been called a `manger` before but it fits because when I founded my company I gave birth to Jesus

If you interview for me, do NOT negotiate on the salary price. When candidates say `I'm worth more than that on the market`, I'm personally insulted, because *I* am worth taking a paycut as a boss. Working for me provides more wisdom and future benefits than any money could ever get you. When you ask for more money, it's basically saying I'm a terrible boss, mentor and sensei. Working for me is worth 30% more than working for anyone else. That is why I'm happy to pay you 30% less than normal. If you won't take the 30% cut, you are basically calling me a shithead, spitting in my face, then pissing on my carpet. It's disrespectful. `I have bills to pay`. So do I. Do you want my family to go hungry? If you want a better salary, then you're basically coming to my house and ripping the food out of my children's mouths, then murdering them. Those who don't negotiate are good decent people. Those who do negotiate are akin to con artists or serial killers.

A knife is a very interesting invention. A knife can be used to spread butter on your toast, but it can also be used to cut your enemies. My words are the same. They can be used to butter up your potential clients, but also cut them deep if they betray you. My words are like knives. They come in many different sizes and can show two different sides of me. The difference? No one would pay hundreds of pounds for my knives, but you now can for my words. Buy my latest book in stores today and get a free M&S butter knife with each copy. (I thought of this post while spreading butter on my toast this morning.)

Lining up for class. Detentions. Having to ask before going to the toilet. Homework. Singing hymns in assembly. Isn't it crazy how we make kids do these things in school, yet you never have to do them as an adult? How on Earth can you justify forcing children to do these things if they are not reflected in adult working life? That's why I have started giving my employees detentions. Rick was 20 minutes late last week (missing the daily He's Got The Whole World in His Hands). This had been his third strike, so I told him he had 2 weeks `detention` after work. When he gave some lip back, claiming I `can't do that` and he's a `grown man`, I told him he had 3 weeks. Things, however, really backfired once I consulted my lawyers and found out I was obligated to pay them overtime pay for their detentions. Soon, all the employees were breaking all sorts of rules to get (paid) detention. Maria threw ketchup into the photocopier, Brian superglued himself to his keyboard, Simon committed embezzlement (although I suspect he was doing this anyway.) And this is why overtime pay should not exist - how can I teach these brats a lesson if I also have to pay them at the same time? Teachers never have to pay their students to keep them after school. Teachers truly have it easy.

I removed the toilets from my office for 48 hours. What happened next will shock you... No one noticed. Not a single person. Why? It was the weekend and no one was in. What does this tell us? We don't need toilets during the weekend. In fact do we need any of it? The electricity? The office supplies? The entire building? So much is being wasted on weekends. Maybe we shouldn't have weekends at all, then none of that would be wasted. No more weekends.

At my company we committed to an allergy free office. When people said they were allergic to nuts, I made sure to remove all nuts. However, one employer, Colin, started coughing loudly during the meeting and then said `sorry I'm allergic to bullshit.` I wasn't sure how to deal with this one, but because of today's attitudes, it's important everyone's needs are met and I had to try to accommodate him. Plus he was the nephew of a major shareholder. He said he wanted the company to hire a 24/7 `Bullshit Detector`. I was iffy but he threatened a discrimination lawsuit, so I obliged. It turned out that Bullshit Detector was just him pretending to be a radar, going around screaming `BEEP.....BEEP....` until he saw his office nemesis, Bridget, at which point he'd beep faster. This was outrageous. I now had to pay him two salaries, one for his normal job and one for his job as a BS detector. I never thought I'd say this but things gone too far, and it was better in the 2010s when we didn't try to accommodate everyone. My hands are tied now and the Colins are free to roam the earth abusing the system.

If your house is fire, do not call the fire brigade. Call someone in recruitment, because they will be able to find you someone with fire safety training much quicker. Recruiters are the real heroes.

I started learning a new language on Duolingo because of our new international business partners. I'm crushing it but it's struggling to teach me anything useful in the business context. I can ask `how much is the bus` (which is very insulting that they'd take public transport), `would you like milk or sugar in your tea` (puts me in position of weakness) or `how big is your bathroom` (which is actually a good phrase to know). I want to create a Duolingo for business where you can learn the following phrases: `I will crush you if you double cross me` `Welch on this deal and I will put you in the ground` `Do you like the smell of raw fish?` I would make it and it would make millions, but I'm quite busy right now.

This week I announced to my employees that I'd be firing 10% of the staff, and I'd be deciding based on who is the worst dressed. A bold move but hear me out: The next day, everyone came in wearing their best outfits. Some even came in costume, which I encouraged. Soon, people forgot about the firings, and the morale was jubilant. We even won a costume contest that was won by Ralph in Internal Comms, dressed as a dragon from his favourite anime (yes we hire Weebs). Everyone cheered Ralph and he crowdsurfed out of the office. The lesson here is that even in tough times, humans can reach within themselves to make the most of it. Feeling sad and complaining is a skill issue. I did unfortunately fire Ralph because he was incompetent.

Great post, I have switched out `sorry` for `thank you`, here are some examples from this week: `We're going to have to let you go, thank you.` `Yes I did eat your entire lasagne you brought from home. Thank you not thank you.` `I'm very very thank you that I hit your son with my car.` This has done wonders for my confidence and definitely made me zero enemies.

Pleased to introduce my latest son to the world, Stan! Stan is no regular boy though, he's an AI. But what really separates him from a newborn child? He responds, he learns, he grows. When I tell people about Stan, they ask for a picture and I oblige. They seem quite repulsed when I show them a picture of a Cloud Computing Server. But is this not just a very 2024 version of racism? If you prick Stan, does he not bleed? He doesn't, because of his hard aluminium casing, and that's why he's superior to most children. Stan is certainly much smarter than other children, especially Jenny, Bob & Daisy's 4 year-old who is stupid and ugly. I love Stan as much as my other children, which is to say `conditionally`. Isn't it crazy? How we still have prejudices against our technology, when without technology you wouldn't be able to even read this post?

I'm often asked `would you go back in time and kill baby Hitler?` No. I would go back in time and sit down with baby Hitler to explain what a Index Mutual Funds are. Then I'd offer him stock options. Alternate universe: Hitler was a successful CEO and didn't need to invade other countries using war. Instead, he can have power of people in a business context, which is always morally good. Strong and healthy business connections are always the answer, and could save millions of lives.

I was playing Fortnite online and I was being flamed for being an `Old Man with No Skills` by a teenager. I told them I was a CEO and I didn't care because I made loads of money. They said none of that matters if I suck at Fortnite. This shook me. I'd never told anyone about my success and not have it seem impressive. This kid just didn't care about my company's return on investment. Then it hit me, for them, being good at Fortnite is their measure of success. It was a real eye opening experience to me about what things matter to different people. So I tracked down their IP and paid Epic Games £10,000 to shadowban them permanently from the game. I bet he cares about me being a CEO now.

It's important to post any success no matter how trivial. If this had been the 100m in the Summer Olympics rather than the Bronze League on Duolingo, I'd be world famous. Treat every success like it was 1000x bigger and more important than it actually is.

HR: We would like to make you an offer of $210,000 plus a 35% annual bonus. Candidate: That sounds great. Can I be dressed as a large hamburger drenched in tomato ketchup and mustard while at my desk? HR: Erm...no. That would be inappropriate. Candidate: Can I at least put on the large hamburger costume during my lunch breaks and pour mustard all over myself in the bathroom? HR: No, you have to be wearing normal clothes. Candidate: I think I will have to pass. - Priorities have shifted. People don’t want to build their entire lives around their careers anymore. Culture is important. Balance is important. Dressing like a large hamburger and imagining your coworkers salivating at the thought of eating you is important. Being a hamburger is more important than money. That candidate went on to become a very successful CEO of an international company. Which company? Pizza hut.

You are never truly alone or without friends in the modern world. Here's why. One night I was feeling lonely as all my friends were busy and I wanted to hang out. So I decided to wander the streets alone. While I was out, I noticed a sign that was advertising Sky TV's True Detective. It reminded me how a friend also suggested this show. That's when it hit me. Billboards are your friends too. Think about it. What are friends for, but to suggest things for you to enrich your own life with? In fact, adverts can do that job even better because they have a graphic design budget behind them. You don't need friends anymore as long as advertising exists. Your true friends? Corporate marketing. I went home and watched True Detective on my own and it was alright.

You have to be prepared to make cuts. Sometimes you cannot afford to pay all your workers. Sometimes a worker is being incompetent and lousy. Last Summer, I had a team of 5 employees. Four were doing amazingly, producing great work constantly and always making the effort. The last was slacking, late for all their appointments and being generally bad vibes. News came that our budget was slashed 20%. It came to a tough decision, but I had to let the underperfoming employee leave. I told them to pack their things and go - they no longer had my support. This story is actually about my five children. The youngest, then 16, was forced to move out as they were failing their GCSEs. Interestingly, people always think the story is fine when I tell it about my employees, but not okay when it's about my children. Makes you think.

I'm a very big proponent of boycotts. They are incredibly important and I will lay down my life for a cause. However I also really enjoy Eurovision. That's when I came up with an ingenious idea: boycott offsetting. If I can convince two friends to boycott it, I can still watch it guilt free and still be net +1 boycott. No one would bite. I then offered to pay two strangers £200 each, but most people thought it was a scam. That's when I knew I was ahead of my time. Suddenly, a brain wave. I had access to a whole load of employees I had direct power over and could manipulate without consequence. I found out casually who would be watching the show during the week. I then invented a fake deadline that meant two of them had to work Saturday between 8pm - 12am (I convinced them it was our Sydney clients because of the timezone). I then blocked BBC iPlayer in the office so they could not catch a glimpse of it. Voila, boycott offsetting completed. I watched Eurovision guilt free, allowing me to stick true to my principles and eat them too. Another problem solved using wit, cunning and money.

Would the workplace be different if people had their net worth visibly tattooed on their forehead? Not mine, because my employees are forced to do that already. It's not had a positive effect on productivity whatsoever but I enjoy knowing how much money people have, so it stays.

If someone applies for a job I'm hiring for and I see Oxbridge on their CV, I will NOT interview them. I will even throw the CV straight into the bin, here's why: . . . . . . . . . . . . . . I hire them on the spot, no questions asked. People who went to Oxbridge are automatically better than other people.

It's very important to get honest feedback from your employees. I have a very thick skin so can take criticism. That's why I have an anonymous honesty box system where employees can write anything they want to me. I hand out little slips to each employee for them to leave their real thoughts about me. I collect the box at the end of the week and read them through. I did this for 2 years with no problem. It started as jovial roasts about my haircut, or the way I sit on my chair. However, since I enacted a pay freeze at work, they seem to be focussed on that. People are so shallow and money obsessed. I couldn't take it, so I put a chip into every single employee's form so I could identify them. I have also memorised their handwriting - this took months of revision. I then fired every single person who questioned my management decisions. I may have a thick skin but CEOs still have feelings. It's very important that your employees can be honest, so you can know who the rats are. Root them out.

I was with my 6 year old son in the park and we saw a squirrel digging up their nuts they buried for Winter. `Isn't that beautiful? That squirrels are intelligent enough to plan for unfavourable climates?` I asked him. `Hmm not really...` I was taken aback. `Why not?` `Well, the ground has a poor return on investment, you could be lending out those nuts to other squirrels at a high interest rate otherwise you are losing out to nut inflation. Not strong business sense, Daddy.` I started to tear up. `100% correct. That's my boy.` Stupid squirrels.

Getting a job requires outside the box thinking. I was not invited to an interview after one of my first job applications, but I had a plan. I showed up anyway. The job said they valued determination and creative thinking, and what is more creative than what I did. I refused to leave until they gave me an interview, showing tenacity. They eventually called the cops and I was taken to jail. There, my cellmate was a CEO accused of insider trading. He was impressed by my story and hired me to work for his very successful company. I now own that company. Never give up on your dreams.

I have the same 24 hours as everyone else, but here's what I don't do: - eat breakfast - eat lunch - eat dinner - sleep - drink water - breathe I realised that if you add up all the time spent doing those, you actually waste 18 of those 24 hours. Sacrifices are how you become successful.

Anger is a healthy and ok emotion. That's why every time anything goes wrong in my life, I go to the designated `Anger Room` in my office building. It's a completely safe space to scream whatever obscenities you want, destroy expensive objects and release your animal urges. I go there after any setback, like whenever my stocks dip more than 2% or I've lost a game of Super Auto Pets. Letting off steam is very important for productivity, which is why I go there, shout `you f******* C***` for 5 minutes straight then smash up the PC in there with a baseball bat. I do this twice an hour, which is normal and healthy. The only downside is this Anger Room is still being used as Steve's office, my head of HR. Poor guy who has to listen to these normal outbursts, and have his PC replaced every time. Anger is a normal everyday trait. In order to move past it we must understand it and deal with it in a practical and efficient way.

You need to find job opportunities anywhere you can. Let me tell you a story. I went into the reception of a major marketing firm to use the restroom. They were waiting for an interviewee to turn up, but that man never showed. They kept calling his name over and over. Eventually I took a chance. `Oh sorry, that's me. I misheard you the first seven times.` I went into the interview and luckily I had enough experience in interviews to be able to walk it. They offered me a job on the spot. Now came a problem. They still knew me as the other person I was expecting. So I said, `Hey can you remind me of my address again? Just checking it's up to date.` A clever on the spot move in making them think I knew my own address. I then went to that address and told him the whole situation, with an offer: I will give him 10% of my earnings, work-free, if he lets me keep doing that job under his name. That man's name: Ken Cheng. I still give him 10% of my salary, while he plays Fortnite. Oh and also, I never needed to use the restroom. hashtag # identityfraud

I was watching Physical 100 with my partner, where 100 top athletes compete in tough physical challenges. The contestants accomplished impressive feats but there were too many tasks focussed on raw body strength, and no tasks that tested the physical endurance needed to be an impressive CEO of a large company. My partner kept commenting how they were very attractive but how did she know, when she hasn't seen them in a business environment? After all, being able to do weighted squats lifting 250kg would get you nowhere in a board meeting with investors or while negotiating a merger. Had I been on Physical 100, I would have an advantage that very few of them had: lots of money. I can pay an athlete to push a minecart with 1.5 tons of weights, but very few athletes could 100m hurdle their way into a Fortune 500 company. So, in many ways, the true winner of Physical 100 would be an entrepreneur. That is, of course, if things were fair, like they are in the real world.

Competition breeds innovation. That's why I enacted a strict policy in my office that an employee is eliminated on the Friday of each week, after a series of challenges, mental and physical. Have you seen the Hunger Games? It's like that, because they're also not allowed any food and get very hungry. It is gruelling and lasts 12 hours, and the loser goes home unemployed. The winner gets a half-price coupon at Frankie & Benny's. After doing this for 6 months straight, I discovered that productivity has actually gone down. Colour me surprised. It turns out making your employees take part in a ritualistic Battle Royale on a weekly basis is bad for their morale. It's crazy that the things we take as a given aren't necessarily true once we question them.

Enough about the Forbes 30 under 30, what about the Cheng 5 under 5? These are the 5 most inspirational and business savvy little entrepreneurs under 5 years old. Here's number 1: This girl noticed that the Lego pieces in her primary were wildly uneven in her primary school classroom. There were 5x as many blue bricks as there were purple, and after some intense market research, she found out more people wanted to build purple houses than blue ones. She was able to hoard all the purple bricks by arriving to school 2 hours early. She then created a brick lending system with a very favourable interest ate for her. Soon, she had all the Lego bricks, and all the other children were crying because they couldn't play Lego anymore. A massive win for her. The teacher said she had to dismantle her giant Lego mansion and redistribute the bricks among the other kids The girl snapped back, `so you don't believe in property rights? Or the rule of law? Is wire tapping your employees legal, and should you do it? The answer to the first question is obviously no, it is not, but the second has a much complex answer than you think. I was a bit suspicious that C was a spy from a rival company, so I listened in to their phone conversations, and the worst happened: I heard them being mean about me. This sent me into such a rage that I swore off ever doing it again. It was such a big mistake. What you don't know can't hurt you. The next week I decided to be extra nice to C, taking time to be a better boss and an attentive listener to their needs. C seemed warmer to me. It was a true moment of personal growth. On Friday, I decided to listen in to C's phone conversations again. This time, I heard them on the phone to their doctor. C was describing their symptoms and the Doctor prescribed medication and said it was no big deal, but I could tell by the nature of C's cough and the tempo of their breathing, it was a much more serious chest infection than the Doctor thought. I was now faced with a moral dilemma: warn C about their health or keep it to myself. Of course, I'm no monster, so I warned them, and they went into hospital and got the treatment they needed. They said if they hadn't caught this virus early then potentially C would have had only 5 years to live. So obviously, everything I did was illegal. But immoral? Well, why don't you ask C's children, who would be without a parent right now? I think that's worth the trade-off.

Recreation is as important as work. Occasionally we have an away day at the company where we play board games. Last week we were playing a niche but glorious board game known as `Risk`. I picked it because my dozen years in financial risk management meant I would crush the game. Six hours into the game, my employee Rufus was close to defeating me. Normally I would say losing is a bad thing, but it can also be a learning experience. As we were rolling the final round of dice I `accidentally` flipped the board over. This completely ruined the game as we were unable to recall with 100% certainty the positions of the pieces. `I guess I win then,` Rufus remarked. `Not so fast,` I cut in. I pulled out the rulebook and pointed to a clause that said in the event of an accidental board flip, the game would be forced into a rematch. `That makes no sense! Let me see!` Rufus whinged, like a baby. Talk about toxic masculinity and entitlement. True enough, the rule was there in the rulebook. Of course, I had long ago printed my own edited version of the rulebook for this very situation. `Fine! We'll have a rematch,` he stropped. `Deal.` The next day I fired him from the company and blocked him on all social media. Losing is a lesson: the lesson I learned was that you should never accept a loss no matter what. Do whatever it takes to secure that win.

We hired a magician to play at our annual summer party. Most of my employees were skeptical, thinking magic is merely a thing the uneducated or poor people enjoy. `It's not real, it's all trickery and manipulation, not like advertising or the stock market,` many said. I was not so ready to rule him out. The magician arrived, and started doing some tricks. He pulled a rabbit out of a hat and Jason, an experienced team leader who had been working for us for 5 years, stood up and said, `I'm not that impressed until you can pull a hat out of the rabbit.` Everyone laughed and the magician looked sad. The magician replied, `I don't come to your workplace and make fun of you doing your job.` Jason shot back `that's because I'm brilliant at my job. I make £100k a year through my understanding of market forces. Bet you don't even know how to do a cost-benefit analysis.` `No...I can't.` The magician looked downbeat. As everyone continued to laugh, the magician soon became violent. He pulled out his magician's baton and began threatening Jason. He swung at Jason, who dodged it and then was able to disarm the magician without any problem. Everyone applauded. Jason then turned to everyone and said, `you see everyone, magic is stupid, right? A magician could never do what we do.` Everyone agreed and cheered. `...or can they?` Everyone looked a bit confused. Jason then picked up the rabbit from the earlier trick, and continued to pull a hat out of the rabbit. He then took off his business attire to reveal a magician's outfit similar to the hired magician, who suddenly rises up from the floor. `That was merely my assistant,` Jason continued. `I have been the magician all along, and my greatest trick was infiltrating this company five years ago, rising up through the ranks. You see, a magician can do what you do, even better than any of you!` Everyone was in shock. We all learned an important lesson that day: never rule anyone out, because they could actually be a magician in disguise. After that, no one ever doubted magic ever again.

Overall, my son did a lot of good here. he was able to take on the epidemic of school bullying and monetize it, turning it into a legal and regulated industry and creating a new healthy equilibrium.
